16.text: So I'm a woman with chronic schizophrenia.

21.text: I might have ended up spending

23.text: most of my life on the back ward of a hospital,

24.text: but that isn't how my life turned out.

27.text: In fact, I've managed to stay clear of hospitals

34.text: That's not to say that I've remained clear

37.text: After I graduated from the Yale Law School and

40.text: got my first law job, my New Haven analyst, Dr. White,

43.text: announced to me that he was going to close his practice

47.text: before I had planned to leave New Haven.

49.text: White had been enormously helpful to me,

52.text: and the thought of his leaving

56.text: sensing that something was terribly wrong,

58.text: flew out to New Haven to be with me.

60.text: Now I'm going to quote from some of my writings:

62.text: "I opened the door to my studio apartment.

64.text: Steve would later tell me that,

66.text: for all the times he had seen me psychotic, nothing

69.text: could have prepared him for what he saw that day.

71.text: For a week or more, I had barely eaten.

76.text: as though my legs were wooden.

78.text: My face looked and felt like a mask.

81.text: I had closed all the curtains in the apartment, so

84.text: in the middle of the day

85.text: the apartment was in near total darkness.

87.text: The air was fetid, the room a shambles.

90.text: Steve, both a lawyer and a psychologist, has treated

93.text: many patients with severe mental illness, and to this day

96.text: he'll say I was as bad as any he had ever seen.

99.text: 'Hi,' I said, and then I returned to the couch,

102.text: where I sat in silence for several moments.

117.text: 'I'm being pushed into a grave. The situation is grave,' I moan.

122.text: I'm scared. Tell them to get away.'"

124.text: As a young woman, I was in a psychiatric hospital

128.text: on three different occasions for lengthy periods.

130.text: My doctors diagnosed me with chronic schizophrenia,

133.text: and gave me a prognosis of "grave."

136.text: That is, at best, I was expected to live in a board and care,

144.text: Instead, I'm a chaired Professor of Law, Psychology

147.text: and Psychiatry at the USC Gould School of Law,

152.text: and I have a beloved husband, Will, who's here with us today.

161.text: He's definitely the star of my show.

165.text: I'd like to share with you how that happened, and also

167.text: describe my experience of being psychotic.

170.text: I hasten to add that it's my experience,

173.text: because everyone becomes psychotic in his or her own way.

175.text: Let's start with the definition of schizophrenia.

181.text: Its defining feature is psychosis, or being

188.text: Delusions are fixed and false beliefs that aren't responsive

191.text: to evidence, and hallucinations are false sensory experiences.

195.text: For example, when I'm psychotic I often have

197.text: the delusion that I've killed hundreds of thousands

201.text: I sometimes have the idea that

202.text: nuclear explosions are about to be set off in my brain.

207.text: like one time I turned around and saw a man

211.text: Imagine having a nightmare while you're awake.

213.text: Often, speech and thinking become disorganized

218.text: Loose associations involves putting together words

221.text: that may sound a lot alike but don't make sense,

224.text: and if the words get jumbled up enough, it's called "word salad."

226.text: Contrary to what many people think, schizophrenia is not

231.text: the same as multiple personality disorder or split personality.

234.text: The schizophrenic mind is not split, but shattered.

238.text: Everyone has seen a street person,

242.text: standing outside of an office building muttering

247.text: This person is likely to have some form of schizophrenia.

249.text: But schizophrenia presents itself across a wide array

252.text: of socioeconomic status, and there are people

254.text: with the illness who are full-time professionals

260.text: to write down my experiences and my personal journey,

264.text: and I want to share some more of that story with you today

268.text: So the following episode happened the seventh week

271.text: of my first semester of my first year at Yale Law School.

276.text: "My two classmates, Rebel and Val, and I had made the date

279.text: to meet in the law school library on Friday night

282.text: to work on our memo assignment together.

284.text: But we didn't get far before I was talking in ways

291.text: 'They make certain points. The point is on your head.

293.text: Pat used to say that. Have you killed you anyone?'

296.text: Rebel and Val looked at me

298.text: as if they or I had been

299.text: splashed in the face with cold water.

303.text: 'Oh, you know, the usual. Who's what, what's who,

306.text: heaven and hell. Let's go out on the roof.

308.text: It's a flat surface. It's safe.'

311.text: and they asked what had gotten into me.

312.text: 'This is the real me,' I announced,

314.text: waving my arms above my head.

316.text: And then, late on a Friday night, on the roof

320.text: I began to sing, and not quietly either.

326.text: 'Are you on drugs?' one asked. 'Are you high?'

331.text: Come to the Florida sunshine bush,

334.text: where there are lemons, where they make demons.'

337.text: 'You're frightening me,' one of them said, and Rebel and Val

344.text: Back inside, I asked my classmates if they were

347.text: having the same experience of words jumping around

351.text: 'I think someone's infiltrated my copies of the cases,' I said.

356.text: I don't believe in joints, but

358.text: they do hold your body together.'" --

359.text: It's an example of loose associations. --

362.text: "Eventually I made my way back to my dorm room,

364.text: and once there, I couldn't settle down.

366.text: My head was too full of noise,

368.text: too full of orange trees and law memos I could not write

372.text: and mass murders I knew I would be responsible for.

375.text: Sitting on my bed, I rocked back and forth,

380.text: This episode led to my first hospitalization in America.

383.text: I had two earlier in England.

387.text: "The next morning I went to my professor's office to ask

389.text: for an extension on the memo assignment,

393.text: as I had the night before,

394.text: and he eventually brought me to the emergency room.

396.text: Once there, someone I'll just call 'The Doctor'

400.text: and his whole team of goons swooped down,

402.text: lifted me high into the air,

403.text: and slammed me down on a metal bed

405.text: with such force that I saw stars.

407.text: Then they strapped my legs and arms to the metal bed

412.text: A sound came out of my mouth that I'd never heard before:

422.text: forced from somewhere deep inside my belly

425.text: This incident resulted in my involuntary hospitalization.

430.text: One of the reasons the doctors gave for hospitalizing me

433.text: against my will was that I was

436.text: To support this view, they wrote in my chart that I was unable

439.text: to do my Yale Law School homework.

441.text: I wondered what that meant about much of the rest of New Haven.

446.text: During the next year, I would

448.text: spend five months in a psychiatric hospital.

450.text: At times, I spent up to 20 hours in mechanical restraints,

454.text: arms tied, arms and legs tied down,

457.text: arms and legs tied down with a net tied

464.text: I never harmed anyone. I never made any direct threats.

467.text: If you've never been restrained yourself, you may have

469.text: a benign image of the experience.

474.text: Every week in the United States,

476.text: it's been estimated that one to three people die in restraints.

479.text: They strangle, they aspirate their vomit,

481.text: they suffocate, they have a heart attack.

484.text: It's unclear whether using mechanical restraints

486.text: is actually saving lives or costing lives.

489.text: While I was preparing to write my student note

491.text: for the Yale Law Journal on mechanical restraints,

494.text: I consulted an eminent law professor who was also

497.text: and said surely he would agree

503.text: He looked at me in a knowing way, and said,

509.text: They're different from me and you.

510.text: They wouldn't experience restraints as we would."

513.text: I didn't have the courage to tell him in that moment that,

516.text: no, we're not that different from him.

518.text: We don't like to be strapped down to a bed

520.text: and left to suffer for hours any more than he would.

525.text: and I'm sure some people still hold it as a view,

527.text: that restraints help psychiatric patients feel safe.

530.text: I've never met a psychiatric patient

534.text: Today, I'd like to say I'm very pro-psychiatry

538.text: I don't think force is effective as treatment, and I think

541.text: using force is a terrible thing to do to another person

545.text: Eventually, I came to Los Angeles

548.text: to teach at the University of Southern California Law School.

550.text: For years, I had resisted medication,

552.text: making many, many efforts to get off.

554.text: I felt that if I could manage without medication,

557.text: I could prove that, after all,

559.text: I wasn't really mentally ill, it was some terrible mistake.

562.text: My motto was the less medicine, the less defective.

565.text: My L.A. analyst, Dr. Kaplan, was urging me

568.text: just to stay on medication and get on with my life,

571.text: but I decided I wanted to make one last college try to get off.

576.text: "I started the reduction of my meds, and within a short time

581.text: After returning from a trip to Oxford, I marched into

584.text: Kaplan's office, headed straight for the corner, crouched down,

588.text: covered my face, and began shaking.

590.text: All around me I sensed evil beings poised with daggers.

593.text: They'd slice me up in thin slices

595.text: or make me swallow hot coals.

597.text: Kaplan would later describe me as 'writhing in agony.'

600.text: Even in this state, what he accurately described as

605.text: I refused to take more medication.

607.text: The mission is not yet complete.

610.text: Immediately after the appointment with Kaplan,

612.text: I went to see Dr. Marder, a schizophrenia expert

615.text: who was following me for medication side effects.

617.text: He was under the impression that I had a mild psychotic illness.

620.text: Once in his office, I sat on his couch, folded over,

625.text: 'Head explosions and people trying to kill.

627.text: Is it okay if I totally trash your office?'

630.text: 'You need to leave if you think you're going to do that,'

633.text: 'Okay. Small. Fire on ice. Tell them not to kill me.

637.text: Tell them not to kill me. What have I done wrong?

638.text: Hundreds of thousands with thoughts, interdiction.'

644.text: I think you need to be in the hospital.

646.text: I could get you admitted right away, and the whole thing

651.text: You're offering to put me in hospitals?

653.text: Hospitals are bad, they're mad, they're sad.

656.text: One must stay away. I'm God, or I used to be.'"

660.text: At that point in the text,

662.text: where I said "I'm God, or I used to be," my husband

665.text: He said, "Did you quit or were you fired?"

668.text: "'I give life and I take it away.

672.text: Forgive me, for I know not what I do.'

674.text: Eventually, I broke down in front of friends, and

677.text: everybody convinced me to take more medication.

680.text: I could no longer deny the truth,

682.text: and I could not change it.

683.text: The wall that kept me, Elyn, Professor Saks,

686.text: separate from that insane woman hospitalized years past,

691.text: Everything about this illness says I shouldn't be here,

694.text: but I am. And I am, I think, for three reasons:

702.text: for decades and continuing, and excellent psychopharmacology.

705.text: Second, I have many close family members and friends who know me

710.text: These relationships have given my life a meaning

712.text: and a depth, and they also helped me navigate

715.text: my life in the face of symptoms.

717.text: Third, I work at an enormously supportive workplace

721.text: This is a place that not only accommodates my needs

726.text: It's also a very intellectually stimulating place,

729.text: and occupying my mind with complex problems

731.text: has been my best and most powerful and most reliable

737.text: Even with all that — excellent treatment, wonderful family and

742.text: I did not make my illness public

746.text: and that's because the stigma against mental illness

748.text: is so powerful that I didn't feel safe with people knowing.

751.text: If you hear nothing else today,

753.text: please hear this: There are not "schizophrenics."

757.text: There are people with schizophrenia, and these people

760.text: may be your spouse, they may be your child,

762.text: they may be your neighbor, they may be your friend,

766.text: So let me share some final thoughts.

768.text: We need to invest more resources into research and treatment

773.text: The better we understand these illnesses, the better

775.text: the treatments we can provide, and the better the treatments

777.text: we can provide, the more we can offer people care,

780.text: and not have to use force.

781.text: Also, we must stop criminalizing mental illness.

784.text: It's a national tragedy and scandal that the L.A. County Jail

788.text: is the biggest psychiatric facility in the United States.

791.text: American prisons and jails are filled with people who suffer

795.text: from severe mental illness, and many of them are there

797.text: because they never received adequate treatment.

799.text: I could have easily ended up there or on the streets myself.

803.text: A message to the entertainment industry and to the press:

806.text: On the whole, you've done a wonderful job fighting stigma

812.text: Please, continue to let us see characters in your movies,

817.text: who suffer with severe mental illness.

821.text: and portray them in all the richness and depth

823.text: of their experience as people and not as diagnoses.

827.text: Recently, a friend posed a question:

829.text: If there were a pill I could take

831.text: that would instantly cure me, would I take it?

837.text: He declined, saying, "Don't take my devils away,

839.text: because my angels may flee too."

841.text: My psychosis, on the other hand,

843.text: is a waking nightmare in which my devils are so terrifying

846.text: that all my angels have already fled.

848.text: So would I take the pill? In an instant.

852.text: That said, I don't wish to be seen as regretting

854.text: the life I could have had if I'd not been mentally ill,

857.text: nor am I asking anyone for their pity.

859.text: What I rather wish to say is that the humanity we all share

862.text: is more important than the mental illness we may not.

865.text: What those of us who suffer with mental illness want

869.text: in the words of Sigmund Freud, "to work and to love."

875.text: Thank you. Thank you. You're very kind. (Applause)
